task: Extract causal relationships: Wind Direction/Sector and Upwind Exposure → PM2.5 in Hanoi

relationships.cause: North and northeast winds during winter period
relationships.mechanism: Long-range transport of air pollutants from highly industrialized areas and intensive fire regions in southern China and Southeast Asia
relationships.evidence_quote: With the predominance of north and northeast winds during the winter period, the long-range transport of air pollutants which emitted from the highly industrialized areas and the intensive fire regions in the southern part of China and Southeast Asia region were likely other important sources for the highly elevated concentrations of PM2.5 and its chemical species in the study area.

source.title: Seasonal Characteristics of Atmospheric PM2.5 in an Urban Area of Vietnam and the Influence of Regional Fire Activities

relationships.effect: Transport of industrial and urban pollutants to Hanoi
relationships.mechanism: Northeast monsoon carries pollutants from mega-urban areas (Chengdu, Chongqing) and industrial sources in southern China
relationships.evidence_quote: General synoptic meteorology patterns indicate northerly winds flowing from South China into Northern Vietnam and Hanoi during October–March... During the peak BC months of December and January, wind patterns indicated pollutant transport from southern China megacity areas.

source.title: Analysis of air pollution over Hanoi, Vietnam using multi-satellite and MERRA reanalysis datasets

relationships.effect: Transport of biomass burning aerosols from Laos and Southern Vietnam to Hanoi
relationships.mechanism: Southeast monsoon carries pollutants from forest fires and slash-and-burn agriculture in Laos and Northwest Vietnam
relationships.evidence_quote: whereas during Apr-Aug more south or southeasterly winds from Laos, Southern Vietnam, and the South China Sea. During March and April, high BC values over Laos and Northwest province of Vietnam are attributed especially to forest fires and slash and burn agriculture.

source.title: Analysis of air pollution over Hanoi, Vietnam using multi-satellite and MERRA reanalysis datasets

relationships.cause: Long-range transport from north and northeast
relationships.effect: Significant contribution to local PM2.5 levels in Hanoi
relationships.mechanism: Air mass backward trajectories and concentration weight trajectory (CWT) analysis reveal pollutant transport pathways
relationships.evidence_quote: The results showed that the contribution of long-range transport from the north and northeast to local PM2.5 levels was significant.

source.title: The effects of meteorological conditions and long-range transport on PM2.5 levels in Hanoi revealed from multi-site measurement using compact sensors and machine learning approach

relationships.effect: Increased air pollutant levels in Hanoi
relationships.mechanism: Air pollutant levels increase over the couple of days following a cold surge due to transport of polluted air masses from the north

conditions.time_lag: Couple of days after cold surge

relationships.evidence_quote: It has been found that air pollutant levels increased over the couple of days that followed a cold surge.

source.title: The effects of meteorological conditions and long-range transport on PM2.5 levels in Hanoi revealed from multi-site measurement using compact sensors and machine learning approach

relationships.cause: Low wind speeds with stagnating ridge over Northern Vietnam
relationships.mechanism: Stagnating high-pressure ridge reduces atmospheric dispersion, allowing PM accumulation from both local sources and long-range transport
relationships.evidence_quote: High 24 h PM levels were observed at low wind speeds when a stagnating ridge governed over Northern Vietnam.

source.title: Effects of local, regional meteorology and emission sources on mass and compositions of particulate matter in Hanoi

relationships.cause: Wind direction relative to local emission sources
relationships.effect: Daily PM2.5 level fluctuations in Hanoi
relationships.mechanism: PM2.5 levels closely linked to wind direction relative to local emission sources, with both local sources and long-range transport contributing

conditions.spatial_relationship: Wind direction relative to local emission sources

relationships.evidence_quote: The daily PM2.5 levels were found to closely link to local wind speeds and directions (relative to local emission sources) and regional synoptic meteorology suggesting that both local sources and LRT contributed to the high PM levels at the site.

source.title: Effects of local, regional meteorology and emission sources on mass and compositions of particulate matter in Hanoi

relationships.cause: Air masses traveling through Pearl River Delta (highly industrialized area)
relationships.effect: Elevated PM2.5 and anthropogenic/biomass burning species concentrations in Hanoi during winter
relationships.mechanism: Air masses from north and northeast directions carry pollutants from industrialized Pearl River Delta region to Hanoi
relationships.evidence_quote: air masses mainly originating from the north and northeast directions travelled through the Pearl River Delta region in the southern part of China (a highly industrialized area) before arriving at the measurement site during the winter period.

source.title: Seasonal Characteristics of Atmospheric PM2.5 in an Urban Area of Vietnam and the Influence of Regional Fire Activities

relationships.effect: Highest concentrations of Cl−, NO3−, Na+, K+, Ca2+, and EC in PM2.5
relationships.mechanism: Southeast wind transports pollutants from industrial sources (cement, steel, coal-fired power plants) in eastern and southern provinces near Hanoi
relationships.evidence_quote: During the summer period, the southeast wind was the most prevailing wind sector... The highest concentrations of Cl−, NO3−, Na+, K+, Ca2+, and EC were corresponding to the southeast wind.

source.title: Seasonal Characteristics of Atmospheric PM2.5 in an Urban Area of Vietnam and the Influence of Regional Fire Activities

relationships.effect: High concentrations of Cl−, NH4+, and Ca2+ in PM2.5
relationships.mechanism: North wind transports pollutants from regional sources including industrial emissions and biomass burning
relationships.evidence_quote: The dominant winds in the winter period were the southeast, northeast, and north winds. The high concentrations of Cl−, NH4+, and Ca2+ were related to the north wind.

source.title: Seasonal Characteristics of Atmospheric PM2.5 in an Urban Area of Vietnam and the Influence of Regional Fire Activities

relationships.cause: Lower wind speed during winter period
relationships.effect: Increased PM2.5 concentrations due to reduced atmospheric dispersion
relationships.mechanism: Lower wind speed and boundary layer height trap air pollutants near the ground surface

conditions.meteorological_factor: Lower wind speed, lower boundary layer height

relationships.evidence_quote: the moderate to strong negative correlations between wind speed and PM2.5 as well as most of PM2.5 chemical species were generally observed for both the summer and winter periods... the lower values of wind speed and boundary layer height during the winter period were favorable for the trapping of air pollutants in the ground.

source.title: Seasonal Characteristics of Atmospheric PM2.5 in an Urban Area of Vietnam and the Influence of Regional Fire Activities

relationships.cause: Intensive fire activities in southern China and Southeast Asia during winter
relationships.effect: Elevated PM2.5 and biomass burning species (SO42−, NH4+, K+, OC, EC) in Hanoi
relationships.mechanism: Air masses traveling across intensive fire regions carry biomass burning pollutants to Hanoi during winter
relationships.evidence_quote: The MODIS fire maps showed that fire sources occurring in the southern part of China and the Southeast Asia region (Vietnam, Laos, Thailand, and Myanmar) during the winter period were much more intensive than those during the summer period. As air masses traveled across the highly industrialized and intensive fire regions during the winter period, they might have carried a large amount of air pollutants.

source.title: Seasonal Characteristics of Atmospheric PM2.5 in an Urban Area of Vietnam and the Influence of Regional Fire Activities

summary.main_finding: Wind direction and upwind exposure are critical factors influencing PM2.5 concentrations in Hanoi, with distinct seasonal patterns. During winter (October-March), north and northeast winds transport pollutants from southern China's industrialized regions and regional biomass burning areas, leading to significantly elevated PM2.5 levels. During summer (April-August), south and southeast winds bring pollutants from Laos, southern Vietnam, and maritime sources.
key_mechanisms: Long-range transport via northeast monsoon from southern China megacities
Biomass burning transport from Laos and Northwest Vietnam
Cold surge events enhancing pollutant transport
Low wind speed and stagnating ridge conditions reducing dispersion
Seasonal wind direction changes affecting source regions
